snippet: DICKLER--Ruth. It is with deep sadness that we note the passing of Mrs. Ruth Dickler who first joined The Citizens Housing & Planning Council as a volunteer in 1962, where she began to build and shape our archival library. She was an important resource for New York City's researchers, academics, and students. Upon her retirement she became a member of CHPC's Board of Directors. A talented writer and editor, her research and organizational skills helped to shape CHPC's work for nearly five decades. A mentor and friend to all of us at CHPC, her legacy continues in the historic library that bares her name. Our heartfelt condolences to her family and friends and to our city which has lost a great lady. 1/3

It is with deep sadness that we note the passing of Mrs. Ruth Dickler who first joined The Citizens Housing & Planning Council as a volunteer in 1962, where she began to build and shape our archival library. She was an important resource for New York City's researchers, academics, and students. Upon her retirement she became a member of CHPC's Board of Directors. A talented writer and editor, her research and organizational skills helped to shape CHPC's work for nearly five decades. A mentor and friend to all of us at CHPC, her legacy continues in the historic library that bares her name. Our heartfelt condolences to her family and friends and to our city which has lost a great lady. 1/3
